awd_titl_txt: Smart Manufacturing and Resources for Transforming the Future
awd_abstract_narration:
Smart Manufacturing and Resources for Transforming the Future (SMART Future) is promoting STEM exploration and education while strengthening the economies of rural areas through training in new manufacturing technologies. By preparing rural high school students for careers in high-growth fields like manufacturing and information technology, SMART Future is advancing new and innovative methods for producing goods, meeting the nation's changing employment needs, and improving educational and earning opportunities for teachers and youth in rural areas.

Through its use of a Mobile Simulation Laboratory, SMART Future is preparing technicians for industrial automation and technology careers and increasing the capacity of rural secondary teachers to provide education in the context of the emerging Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) and Industry 4.0. The project goals are to expand STEM opportunities and prepare technicians for manufacturing and engineering careers through applied education of IIoT and Industry 4.0 concepts; and increase the capacity of rural secondary teachers to provide instruction in industrial automation. Drawing on industry expertise, SMART Future is providing dual credit for learning STEM principles in industrial automation, including programmable logic controllers (PLCs), microcontrollers, robotics, automated processes, machine-to-machine learning, computer networking and programming, applied mathematics, engineering design, precision measurement, physics, and mathematical logic.

por.por_cntn:
The Smart Manufacturing and Resources for Transforming the Future (SMART Future) project promoted STEM education and opportunities for students in rural Wisconsin communities. The project brought together rural high school technology instructors, technical college faculty, and industry professionals to design and deliver instruction in Industry 4.0, supply chain, and automation concepts via a Mobile Manufacturing Laboratory, all while increasing the long-term access of rural populations to education in advanced technology.

During week-long professional development workshops, high school instructors from four rural Wisconsin schools received instruction on equipment and simulations. This training enabled them to deliver learning modules in advanced manufacturing to their students with the assistance of the mobile lab’s technician. Educational modules were delivered via 9-week sessions when the Mobile Laboratory brought equipment to four different rural Wisconsin High Schools.

The experiences of the high school students with the Mobile Lab led to the earning of industry-recognized credentials that help them transition to college or employment. Almost 600 rural Wisconsin High School students engaged in the Mobile Lab experience, and 644 unique industry and academic credentials were earned by these students over the duration of the project.

By increasing the capacity of rural secondary teachers to provide instruction in industrial automation, and by preparing rural high school students for careers in high-growth fields like manufacturing, automation, and information technology, the SMART Future project helped advance new and innovative methods for producing goods, thus helping to meet the nation's changing employment needs and improve educational and earning opportunities for teachers and youth in rural areas.

 


Last Modified: 11/01/2021
Modified by: Shamus Funk
